1.a: Paul give thanks to God for their growing faith and for their love toward each other.
1.q: For what two things in the church at Thessalonica does Paul give thanks to God?

1.a: The believers are enduring persecutions and afflictions.
1.q: What circumstances are the believers enduring in Thessalonica?

1.a: The believers will be counted worthy of the kingdom of God.
1.q: What will be the positive result of the circumstances the believers are enduring?

1.a: God will afflict those who afflict the believers, punishing them with flaming fire.
1.q: What will God do to those who afflict the believers?

1.a: The believers will be relieved when Jesus Christ is revealed from heaven.
1.q: When will the believers be relieved of their afflictions?

1.a: The punishment for those who do not know God will be eternal.
1.q: How long will the punishment be for those who do not know God?

1.a: Those who do not know God are separated from the presence of the Lord as part of their punishment.
1.q: From what are those who do not know God separated as part of their punishment?

1.a: The believers will marvel at Christ when he comes on his day.
1.q: What will the believers do when they see Christ come on his day?

1.a: The result of their good works is that the name of the Lord Jesus Christ is glorified.
1.q: What is the result of the believers' good works of faith done in God's power?

2.a: Paul says he is now going to write concerning the coming of the Lord Jesus Christ.
2.q: About what event does Paul say he is now going to write?

2.a: Paul tells them not to believe that the day of the Lord has already come.
2.q: What does Paul tell them not to believe?

2.a: The falling away and the revealing of the man of lawlessness must come before the day of the Lord.
2.q: What does Paul say must come before the day of the Lord?

2.a: The man of lawlessness opposes and exalts himself against God, sitting in the temple of God and portraying himself as God.
2.q: What does the man of lawlessness do?

2.a: The man of lawlessness will be revealed when it is time, when the one who restrains him is taken out of the way.
2.q: When will the man of lawlessness be revealed?

2.a: When Jesus is revealed, he will kill the man of lawlessness.
2.q: What will Jesus do to the man of lawlessness when Jesus is revealed?

2.a: Satan is working with the man of lawlessness to give him power, signs, and false wonders.
2.q: Who is working with the man of lawlessness to give him power, signs, and false wonders?

2.a: Some are deceived because they did not receive the love of the truth that they might be saved.
2.q: Why are some deceived by the man of lawlessness and are perishing?

2.a: Those who are deceived and perishing take pleasure in unrighteousness.
2.q: In what do those who are deceived and perishing take pleasure?

2.a: God chose for the Thessalonians to obtain the glory of the Lord Jesus Christ through the gospel.
2.q: What did God choose for the Thessalonians to obtain through the gospel?

2.a: Paul calls the Thessalonians to stand firm and to grasp the traditions that they were taught.
2.q: What does Paul call the Thessalonians to do now that they have received the gospel?

2.a: Paul desires that the Thessalonians be established in every good work and word.
2.q: In what does Paul desire the Thessalonians to be established in their hearts?

3.a: Paul wants the Thessalonians to pray that the word of the Lord would spread rapidly and be glorified.
3.q: For what does Paul want the Thessalonians to pray regarding the word of the Lord?

3.a: Paul wishes to be delivered from wicked and evil people who do not have faith.
3.q: From whom does Paul wish to be delivered?

3.a: Paul tells the Thessalonians to continue to do the things he has commanded them.
3.q: What does Paul tell the Thessalonians to continue to do?

3.a: The believers are to avoid every brother who lives idly.
3.q: What are the believers to do with every brother who lives idly?

3.a: Paul labored night and day, paying for his food, and not being a burden to anyone.
3.q: What example did Paul set for the Thessalonians regarding his work and support?

3.a: Paul commanded that anyone who does not want to work should not eat.
3.q: What did Paul command concerning anyone who does not want to work?

3.a: Paul commands the lazy to work with quietness and to eat their own food.
3.q: Instead of being lazy, what does Paul command such people to do?

3.a: The brothers are to have no association with anyone who does not obey Paul's instruction in this letter.
3.q: What are the brothers to do with anyone who does not obey Paul's instruction in this letter?

3.a: Paul desires that the Lord would give the Thessalonians peace at all times in all ways.
3.q: What does Paul desire that the Lord would give the Thessalonians?

3.a: Paul wrote the greeting with his own hand as the sign that he is the author.
3.q: How does Paul show that he is the author of this letter?
